title: Monday, 8th April 2019

Given that Corbyn's overriding priority is to reduce social inequality, it is nigh on a certainty that he and McDonnell will meddle with pensions like Brown did. This time around, it is likely Labour will restrict the ability of many workers to build half-decent retirement funds by reducing the tax relief boost currently available.

11:09 am

JP11:09am

A. M. @Flaneur: are they talking up their own book, after a fashion?
BE11:10am

Tom Selby, senior analyst at financial firm AJ Bell, says a Corbyn-led Labour government represents an 'existential threat' to pension tax relief for high earners. Charles Calkin, a financial planner at James Hambro & Partners, says higher rate relief is 'doomed'.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

\o/

JP11:10am

Here's one that applies to the entire population:

JP11:10am

PAY THE SCHOOL FEES IN ADVANCE

If you have children at a fee paying school, see if the bursar is prepared to offer a discount on fees paid in advance, covering multiple years.

Although this will not allow you to escape Labour’s plan to charge 20 per cent VAT on private school fees – the levy is due when a service is delivered – it will at least help you to mitigate the cost.

Flaneur They're talking up something, thats for sure...
FATDAZ Ironic that Corbyn would act to reduce tax benefits on pensions when his own nest is so nicely feathered
11:10 am

Tom Dalgleish UK school fees are more than double that in Oz and I wonder why

Anyway, if you're at home looking after the kids, it's worth a read.

11:12 am

BE11:21am

Aston Martin had a strong 2018 in terms of unit sales with wholesale volumes growing by as much as 26%, to 6.4k units. However, we expect global automotive market volatility and Brexit-related uncertainty to depress customer demand from here, on top of lower ASPs yoy.

BE11:21am

With muted demand momentum forecast in the short-term, but increasing fixed costs already, due to St Athan ramping up, we see a risk to earnings in 2019. To us, the DBX launch, late this year, has always been the key story and remains the key trigger of the stock; but with deliveries of that model still several months out, we see limited share price potential in the meantime. Additionally, we observed much higher volatility in demand versus its peer, Ferrari, closer in fact to the premium OEMs', like BMW, which prompts us to lower our applied multiple by about 30%. In line with previous company communications, we have been of the view that Aston Martin would be less exposed to end-market volatility but we somewhat revise that view, on the back of a slowdown in Aston's key markets, Germany and the UK, weighing on sales momentum. With all this in mind, we lower our target price by 50% to GBP10, of which 20ppt is due to earnings revisions, and 30ppt to a lower multiple. Hence, we downgrade to Hold on valuation grounds.

Flaneur AVs bete noir - Mr Musk - is responsible for a lot of this. His output has put ICE supercars to shame. Gonna need to go electric, at least partially.

BE11:47am

Downgrading to Neutral after another profit warning
Our Buy rating was predicated on Saga's higher multiple travel and broking units offsetting normalising reserve releases, driving a re-rating. With Saga's FY18 results, the company reset expectations around broking profitability, highlighting unsustainable margins, with outer year profit expectations declining ~40%. Saga in turn announced a new strategy, renegotiated covenants with the banks and cut the dividend. After falling ~35%, the shares trade on 8x 2019E PE for a 6% yield. Since its IPO, Saga has now profit warned twice and removed its medium term earnings growth guidance. We find further execution risks around the new strategy, which we expect to weigh on the PE multiple. We cut 2020-24E EPS 38-44%, lower our PT to 65p, downgrading to Neutral.

Execution risks around new strategy high, management track record limited
There are two main types of UK motor / home insurer:1) the lean, efficient, price comparison website ("PCW") distributor, and2) the direct distributor with a unique value proposition. Saga's brand lends itself to no.2, but recently it has sought growth from the lower margin PCW channel, whilst extracting higher margins than perhaps the product commands. Saga now notes this is unsustainable, and will refocus on direct channels, whilst investing in new products, and normalising the margin, which hits earnings. At the heart of this strategy is a 3 year fixed price product, which we believe brings risks around capital requirements in the broking unit, and claims inflation.

Risks increasing around the FCA's industry pricing investigation
Another headwind to earnings was Saga changing its renewal practices, in the context of the ongoing FCA investigation. Saga is tapering the margin it earns on some of its highly profitable back book home products. Saga had already performed this exercise before, givens its potentially vulnerable customer demographic. These actions represent a greater than £10-15m earnings headwind off a base of ~£100m. Whilst we suspect Saga has been prudent here given it was already rebasing earnings, our sense is that risks are increasing around this investigation with companies starting to act now; particularly for those with exposure to home - Direct Line (~20% of profit) and RSA (~10-15%).

BE12:01pm

We believe many investors are underestimating the severity of the challenges and underlying risks at GE, while overestimating the value of small positives, and with a 38% move in the stock year to date, and more than 50% cuts to forward fundamental FCF anchors, we are cutting our PT and moving to UW. The
driver of the downgrade is our view that the Street is significantly over
projecting the bounce in FCF in the coming years, off levels that we calculate at zero currently, as Power/Renewables remains weak, GECS will likely consume material cash for the foreseeable future, Aviation fundamentals, as per underlying FCF, are weaker than meet the eye, while lingering sector high leverage including entitlements leaves the company vulnerable to liquidity issues in the event of a recession, for which a potentially dilutive sale of the rest of Healthcare may be needed. We question why some on the Sell Side appear to be cutting billions out of FCF estimates but maintaining PTs. Putting aside all the noise around industrial SOTP analyses that are now almost irrelevant and even a stubbornly heavy debt/entitlement burden, our new $5 PT is simply a sector multiple on 2021 FCF, discounted back a year.
